audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a question about starting camp for Kevin Lee. A male speaker responds, stating he doesn't have a start date but is always training, increasing the intensity, and is "in the thick of it right now." His tone suggests dedication and effort. He also mentions coming home sore and needing rest. In the background, there's a sound that resembles a door slam, although the exact nature remains uncertain.

The audio clip begins with a man asking a question about putting "real estate on the back burner." Another man responds affirmatively, indicating he has an open house tomorrow. The first man is briefly heard laughing. The second man adds that "the house will sell tomorrow and that's it." Another voice interjects with "how many bedrooms?", followed by laughter. The speaker then says "legally?".

The audio clip features two male speakers engaging in a casual conversation. The first speaker is laughing while the other asks, "What are your appetite?" This is followed by someone requesting that the previous comment be edited out. The second speaker then asks a question about how Kevin's game has improved. The first speaker acknowledges Kevin is bigger, stronger and more mature as a fighter, although seemingly less mature as a person. The first speaker states that Kevin is polished and seasoned, having been in the ring with tough guys.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a conversational tone. He speaks about an opponent's perceived cockiness upon entering the UFC and how he humbled him, causing the opponent to change his life and move to Vegas. The speaker feels he has been in the opponent's head and acknowledges the opponent's hard work, moving to a new camp because he thinks it is a better team, so he knows the opponent is serious and coming to put it on him.

The audio clip primarily features a male speaker discussing his relationships with his team, mentioning names like "Ray," "Matt," "Fobola," "Aljo," and "Wideman." He describes having a strong bond and feeling like they're a family, contrasting it with his opponent's possible lack of such support. He acknowledges that it won't win him the fight, but highlights the amount of work he's put in. The tone is conversational and thoughtful.

The clip features one male speaker discussing his upcoming fight and past grievances with a prior match. He expresses confidence and a strong desire to win, stating that he has to beat this guy, and contrasts his current preparation with the previous fight where injuries and timing were off. He describes his opponent as tough, possibly tougher than a previous adversary. He recalls watching his opponent's last fight, describing it as brutal and vowing to inflict similar punishment. The conversation seems to be taking place in a workout or training environment, as there is ambient background noise and faint sounds that imply some kind of ongoing activity.

The audio clip features a male speaker, confident in tone, stating, "I think it's in my favor." He elaborates, mentioning cardio and the length of time being an advantage. He repeats, "I think it's in my favor."

The audio clip features one male speaker, identified as Kevin, who has been "awfully quiet lately." There's a pause, followed by another male speaker discussing how he shoved it in Conor's face for talking about his "real estate," and how it made him feel good about himself.  The speaker seems confident and perhaps a little smug. Background ambiance includes indistinct sounds with varying volume.

The audio begins with a male speaker, referencing "Joe Rogan" and "John Kavanagh", indicating he "loved it" and thought it was "well deserved". He describes "putting on a freaking" performance and fighting "his ass off", suggesting an appreciation for their support. His tone is conversational and appreciative.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing an upcoming fight on Big Fox, expressing interest in the event's significance. His tone is conversational. He continues, noting the uniqueness of the event and casually agreeing with a previous statement. A second male voice then asks about Conor McGregor's tweets. The first speaker responds, recounting viewing the fight while under the influence. He recounts specific feelings related to the fight and fighter, citing “you fucking pussy.” He expresses his negative sentiment over the fighters actions stating, “if you talk all that and then you lose, you gotta allow him to you know finish you.” He concludes, expressing a personal hope to not behave in such a way. Another male asks if the fighter has a certain fighting instinct. The first speaker speculates about the fighter's changed mentality since gaining wealth, implying a lack of the drive he once had.

The audio clip consists of speech. A male speaker discusses the saying "satin sheets" and how it relates to waking up and running, suggesting that it captures a particular attitude. The speaker has a casual, conversational tone. There are no discernible background sounds or other audio features.

The audio begins with two speakers, both male, discussing a sports figure and controversy around the statement "it's only business in the corner," regarding its potential meaning, with one speaker expressing uncertainty about whether the statement was even made. One speaker then presents a possible interpretation that the athlete was tired in the third round, and was trying to ease up without explicitly saying so. The speaker pivots to apologize for potentially making light of a serious issue, recognizing that their companion is taking the matter seriously. They conclude by suggesting that the athlete's statement might be a way to mitigate the severity of the situation.

The audio begins with a male voice expressing surprise and excitement, saying, "How'd you feel seeing Khabib fly out of the octagon like that?" and describing the situation as "crazy." There's a brief laugh, followed by another male speaker who seems to be more composed, stating "we were all sitting there just like what is going on right now, this is insane." He then adds, "Good for him." Further laughter occurs before a third speaker poses a question about the bus incident, asking if it makes the situation feel even now. The second speaker then replies stating, "I don't want to be."

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing a past incident, describing it as "a little more criminal" and lamenting that "innocent girls on the bus" and "UFC employees" were targeted. He recounts being on the bus during the event, expressing the belief that they were all going to die and highlighting the frightening experience of things flying through the window. He then mentions someone named Reed Harris, asking "what's going on?". The speaker's tone suggests a mix of seriousness and recollection.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker humorously recounting a story about another person's reaction during turbulence, mentioning a "airplane position." There is some indistinct background chatter. The speaker shifts to discuss the aftermath of a different event, noting Dana White's reaction and the general "hang-wringing." Another person, seemingly male, asks about enjoying the event and whether there was a desire for "revenge," referring to an earlier event where someone "got to get his hands on Connor in the cage." The first speaker responds that he doesn't want to get into that, that at the time he thought it was funny, and he is not a "revenge person." A third person, seemingly male, asks if there's any chance that if he were to "beat Kevin," he would fight "Connor."

The clip begins with a male speaker stating "Absolutely. Yeah. I just I gotta win that fight for sure," and expressing his positive outlook for the upcoming fight. Transitioning slightly, he shares his thoughts on his opponent, and that he had wished to fight a different opponent, but that he feels good about this particular fight because his fighter "looks the best he's looked". Concluding, he says "Thanks guys", before the clip ends.
